item.title: Peter John Landin
item.description:
• wiki
  • ç»´åŸº

I was long curious about how does Î» calculus become the foundation of formalizaing programming languages. Itâ€™s strange that I havenâ€™t look up the answer until today: Itâ€™s invented so early by Alonzo Church (whom I will write another post for) as an alternative mathematic foundation in 1930s and its relation with programming language was re-discoverred in 1960s.

From the â€œLambda calculus and programming languagesâ€ section of wikipedia page:

As pointed out by Peter Landinâ€™s 1965 paper â€œA Correspondence between ALGOL 60 and Churchâ€™s Lambda-notationâ€

I found this name quite familiar since I read his paper â€œThe mechanical evaluation of expressionsâ€ before, in which he introduced the first abstract machine for functional programming language, namely SECD machine. This paper also define the term Closure which becomes a prevalent notion in computer programming nowadays.

Besides of that, his contributions also include:

  • on ALGO definition
  • ISWIM programming language
  • off-side rule, known as â€œindentation-basedâ€ syntax nowadays, popularized by Miranda, Haskell, Python, etc.
  • coin the term syntactic sugar

He was much influenced by a study of McCarthyâ€™s LISP and taught Tony Hoare ALGO with Peter Naur and Edsger W. Dijkstra. (Oh yes, definitely 4 more people to write).

I have just download his old, influential paper â€œThe next 700 programming languagesâ€. I am sure it will be an enjoyable read.
